rename.from: [GOV] recent GOV proposals by aiwalter remove separation of powers, disenfranchise minorities
rename.to: [GOV] recent GOV proposals by aiwalter remove separation of powers, disenfranchise minorities - how to proceed

body:
From a procedural perspective, I suggest:

* move recent GOV content into the [community council repository](https://github.com/sktime/community-org) where it belongs. Discuss proposals to central decision making structure as minuted agenda points, attach change proposals as appendices. 
* properly use the CC meetings and developer meetings for progressing decision on this, instead of posting messages on `sktime` internal channels. Use these for pointers to agendas.
* We have [done that in the past](https://github.com/sktime/community-org/tree/main/community_council/previous_meetings) every two weeks, so why do we now suddenly plaster this everywhere out of procedural order?
* arguments for/against should be written up clearly and discussed in a defined frame.
* block any mechanisms where those shouting loudest win by default, e.g., decision making by social chat channels like slack

rename.from: [GOV] recent GOV proposals by aiwalter remove separation of powers, disenfranchise minorities - how to proceed
rename.to: [GOV] recent GOV proposals by aiwalter - how to proceed

body:
Further, as the chair of the code of conduct committee, I will strictly enforce, by forced timeouts if necessary, in public GitHub spaces and on internal `sktime` channels:

* the [sktime code of conduct](https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/get_involved/code_of_conduct.html). This includes overt violations like putdowns, but also more difficult to spot bullying and harassment tactics like [POV railroading](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:POV_Railroad).
* proper process, such as using the CC meetings as a forum, ensuring that minutes are written, confirmed, and shared. The general point here is that [we need to adhere to process to ensure trustworthiness of the result](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Settle_the_process_first)

In addition, I do recognize the constant well-being burden that the current emotional state of the various public and internal discussion channels on `sktime` puts on participants and onlookers - therefore, I will also strictly ensure that this is remedied before we move on to any decision making.

I recognize that in the entire discussion, I am not the uninvolved party which the CoC committee should optimally be.

Having said that, the topic affects all of `sktime` governance architecture and the very future of `sktime`, including the role that the CoC committee is allowed to play, so probably no contributor to `sktime` is truly uninvolved. Further, [moderators taking action are typically at risk themselves of becoming targets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Administrators_willing_to_make_difficult_blocks).

I will simply do the best I can to keep the community safe and healthy.

issue.title: [GOV] Evolution of sktime governance

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
This issue aims to identify sections in sktime governance that are "undemocratic". General idea of this discussion is to give more power to the core developers to avoid that individuals can take hostage of sktime. 

Undemocratic in this context are for example current gov items:
- Single individuals can block nomination of CC or CoC members, 
see #3939
- CC can supersede core dev votes. This can lead to offending majority of core devs,
see #3937
- CC and CoC nominations are currently for lifetime. This should be changed, so a nomination ends e.g. after 2 years. Then another core dev vote has to happen. This is common practice in any org that claims to have a democratic governance. 
see #3868
- Separation of power between CC and CoC, currently there is no separation on member level.
see #3870

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I will make separate PRs for the different topics. Discussion can happen at PR. General discussion can happen at this issue.

issue.title: [ENH] turning `sklearn` into a soft dependency

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Following the same logic as in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3567 I hereby propose:

I think we should turn `sklearn` into a soft dependency, since it is not core to the framework, but used only in specific estimators. 

---

key arguments for:

* the only key change is giving users the choice `sklearn` yes/no
* for users with `sklearn` installed, the `sktime` experience remains precisely the same
  * users without `sklearn` will be able to use `sktime`, currently they cannot
  * users without `sklearn` will still be able to find `sklearn` based estimators using `all_estimators`, similar to other soft dependencies
* it should be easier to upgrade `sktime` to newer python or package versions, of core dependencies, as `sklearn` is slow to update compatibility
* sklearn is constantly broken
* architectural: reduces coupling, increases layer separation; minimize soft dependencies, see context below

key arguments against:

I don't really see any except the work required

---

Update: more context on architectural and usage benefits.

the general desideratum is "minimize dependencies". This is an explicit architectural north star of scikit-learn as well as sktime.

See e.g., this paper on sklearn design,
https://mblondel.org/publications/lbuitinck-ecmlpkdd2013.pdf
search for "dependencies" in the text.

In the past 6 months, we have made the interfaces of estimators much clearer, including that we can manage python versions and package dependencies on the estimator level, rather than at the sktime package level

This has prompted multiple lines of refactoring around "minimize dependencies":

* migrate sktime-dl into sktime because we can isolate tensorflow to estimators
* isolate `statsmodels`
* newly added annotation module soft dependencies are fully isolated

`statsmodels` isolation and soft dep is very similar, see this PR: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3821

---

FAQ

> does this remove `sklearn` support from `sktime`?

No, `sklearn` will still be supported and used in estimators.
It will only change to be optional, for people who do not want (or need) to use estimators that depend on `sklearn`.

> will this impact performance of `sktime`?

No. For users who have `sklearn` installed, the experience is precisely the same. The logic of `sklearn` based estimators stays the same.

No change in estimator accuracy or speed. (evidence: look at the tests in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3843 which test for both)

The only change is that users get a choice whether they want `sklearn` or not.

issue.title: [ENH] turning `Pandas` into a soft dependency

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Following the same logic as in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3567 I hereby propose:

I think we should turn `Pandas` into a soft dependency, since it is not core to the framework (it is possible to run any estimator with `numpy` input), but used only in specific estimators / situations. 

---

key arguments for:

* the only key change is giving users the choice `Pandas` yes/no
* for users with `Pandas` installed, the `sktime` experience remains precisely the same
  * users without `Pandas` will be able to use `sktime`, currently they cannot
  * users without `Pandas` will still be able to find `Pandas` based estimators using `all_estimators`, similar to other soft dependencies
* it should be easier to upgrade `sktime` to newer python or package versions, of core dependencies, as `Pandas` is slow to update compatibility
* Pandas is constantly broken
* architectural: reduces coupling, increases layer separation; minimize soft dependencies, see context below

key arguments against:

I don't really see any except the work required

---

Update: more context on architectural and usage benefits.

the general desideratum is "minimize dependencies". This is an explicit architectural north star of scikit-learn as well as sktime.

See e.g., this paper on sklearn design,
https://mblondel.org/publications/lbuitinck-ecmlpkdd2013.pdf
search for "dependencies" in the text.

In the past 6 months, we have made the interfaces of estimators much clearer, including that we can manage python versions and package dependencies on the estimator level, rather than at the sktime package level

This has prompted multiple lines of refactoring around "minimize dependencies":

* migrate sktime-dl into sktime because we can isolate tensorflow to estimators
* isolate `statsmodels`
* newly added annotation module soft dependencies are fully isolated

`statsmodels` isolation and soft dep is very similar, see this PR: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3821

---

FAQ

> does this remove `Pandas` support from `sktime`?

No, `Pandas` will still be supported and used in estimators.
It will only change to be optional, for people who do not want (or need) to use estimators that depend on `Pandas`.

> will this impact performance of `sktime`?

No. For users who have `Pandas` installed, the experience is precisely the same. The logic of `Pandas` based estimators stays the same.

No change in estimator accuracy or speed. (evidence: look at the tests in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3843 which test for both)

The only change is that users get a choice whether they want `Pandas` or not.

The only change is that users get a choice whether they want `scipy` or not.

issue.title: [GOV] proposal: CC and CoC should have disjoint membership

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
#3865


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
This adds separation of power between CC and CoC. A person should not be able to have the two positions at same time due to separation of power. This is a typical principle of democracy.
